revised_title: Extra-pair Copulations and Paternity in Shags: Female Mate Choice and Reproductive Success
tldr: This study examines the relationship between extra-pair copulations and paternity in shags, investigating whether females choose better males for mating. DNA fingerprinting was used to identify extra-pair paternity in chicks, and observations of courtship and mating activities were recorded. The results show that females who failed to successfully breed had more extra-pair copulations, suggesting that females solicit these copulations to enhance the genetic quality of their offspring. This supports the hypothesis that females choose better males for mating, leading to better reproductive success.
